content.description:
Great Traverse. 

  Pumpy at the grade. The hands look fine, but once you've been on them for a while they get pumpy, especially if you are in a bouldering mindset. 

  Feet are key for this traverse, as they are polished and sparse in places. Use the good hands to traverse left or right and top out if you desire.   In my opinion, traversing right to left then following the arete to topout up by Satan On A Halfshell (V10) is the most classic of the variations on this line. 

  The right beta will make this climb seem V2, without that beta this climb might seem more like V3+
content.protection: Pad, and someone to move it for ya!
content.location: Obvious horizontal line 5 feet off the ground.

content.description:
Sit start on left end of Umbrella Boulder and follow it to the tree and drop off. No super hard moves on this route just classic good fun, a good warm up for time spent on the harder routes in the area. 

  If you campus the top half I would call it V1, just a fun extra thing to do.

The currently undone line of slopey crimps, sidepulls, and big moves. Start in the Umbrella Traverse holds about 3 ft right of Satan on a Halfshell on a pair of incuts below a big right-facing flake. There are a few edges that extend about 6' up from the start, then the ok holds run out and it's up to you to figure out how to use the microscopic flakes and slopey sidepulls to get to the topout. 

  The most probable sequence involves either a massive RH lockoff/LH bump sequence or a wild spring-loaded LH deadpoint to the crimp at the top of the seam (about a foot below the huge right-angled outcropping, where the seam goes from vertical to horizontal). From this hold, many options exist above for your right but the most obvious choice is to do a big dynamic move to the incredibly positive lip.
content.location: To the right of Satan on a Halfshell. There are a pair of deep incuts and a big right-facing flake that are pretty close to, if not the same as, the start holds for Satan on a Halfshell. There should be a sloping right-angling edge about 2' above/right of the flake and a flat crimp about 2' above that.

content.description: The direct start to Satan on a Halfshell. A superior problem in my opinion. Start to the left of Satan on a Halfshell with your left hand on an incut finger jug and your right hand on a sidepull. Throw up a right heel, utilizing two very small right hand crimps and a left hand slot that all take body tension and precision to stick. Getting your feet on the start holds, deadpoint up to a left hand crimp, hold the swing, and make one more crimpy move to the lip. Topout is cake...
content.location: Smack dab in the middle of the umbrella boulder.

content.description:
A New England classic. Head straight up and out the overhang. Many different sequences will get you most of the way up the boulder, but the crux for most will be the last couple moves, when you can no longer keep your feet down low. 

  Apparently this was originally a v8 when Sherman sent it, using a blowtorch to dry the holds. The upper jug exfoliated, leaving the problem in its current state. Dave Graham got the first re-ascent.

An interesting route with a hard first move. 

  Sit start low with a few options for holds and make a toss up and left to a good sloper (crux). Get you body position right and make fun moves leading to a dead-point to the huge jug. Get a quick rest then fire the top. All the holds at the top are good but the amount of lichen up there is less than inspiring. 

  The start can feel impossible until you get the positioning just right.
content.location: The right arete of the Umbrella Boulder from a low sit start.

content.description:
This is a hard and friction dependent compression climb found on the right side of the boulder.

 Stand start with a terribly slopey left hand sidepull found on the glassy false arete. Reach out right and grab a good right hand incut sidepull. Find some feet and hug your way onto the wall, trusting that there is enough friction to stay on the left hand. Figure out some tricky feet and smack up right hand to a nice openhand sloper pinch on the arete. A hard move to the seam for the left hand gains a positive hold, which is then followed by another right hand move to a pinch. From here, figure out a sequence to reach up to the giant horn four feet up. Continue up and left following positive holds on the arete to the jugs at the lip of the boulder. Topout a few feet off the deck on buckets!
content.location: This climb is found on the right side of the large boulder, just left of the V6 named "Extendo Reacho". This climb and "Extendo Reacho" share the same topout.Â

content.description: This boulder has an obvious well-chalked traverse (Umbrella Traverse V2) as well as a few straight up lines including Satan on a Halfshell (V10).   This boulder, especially the traverse, can be used as a decent warm-up for other probelms in the Blackjacks, also for sport climbers heading up to Starship Enterprise, Triple Corners, and other Northwest Crags.   In spring the base of this boulder can be a mud pit. Look around there might be a tarp to put your pad down on off to the right somewhere... Don't rely on the tarp though, bring your own so your pad won't be covered in mud. Just remember to pack it out, don't leave it there.
